title: Notelock
statementHtml:
Teto is playing the hit rhythm game osu!. The game can be described by a binary string∗∗ ss of length nn and a positive integer kk where the following will happen in order:

You dislike Teto (for some reason). So determine the minimum number of positions you need to protect to force her to leave ss unchanged.

∗∗A binary string is a string that only consists of characters 00 and 11.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each testcase contains integers nn and kk (2≤n≤10002≤n≤1000; 2≤k≤n2≤k≤n) — the length of ss and kk.

The second line of each test case contains a binary string ss of length nn consisting of characters 00 and 11.

The sum of nn across all testcases does not exceed 10001000.
outputSpecHtml: For each testcase, output the minimum number of positions you need to protect to force Teto to leave the string unchanged.
noteHtml:
For the first testcase, you can protect the first element and have: s=11s=11. Now Teto cannot change s1s1 because it is protected and cannot change s2s2 because s1=1s1=1. It can be proven this is optimal.

For the second testcase, you can protect only the first element and have s=100001s=100001. Teto cannot change s1s1 because it is protected and she cannot change s6s6 because there is 11 in the previous k−1k−1 elements (100001100001).

For the fourth testcase, you must protect s1,s3,s5,s7s1,s3,s5,s7 and have s=1010101s=1010101. It can be shown that this is optimal. For example, if you did not protect s3s3, then Teto can change it to 00 (10101011010101)
